Let’s now deal with the shortwave (solar) side of the energy budget.

children.label: Absorbed Shortwave Radiation (ASR) and Planetary Albedo

children.value: First let’s define a new term:
The incoming solar (shortwave) radiation at the top of Earth’s atmosphere.

Teq_new = equilibrium_temperature(0.32,Q,0.57)

The above exercise shows us that if some properties of the climate system change in such a way that the
receives more energy from the sun than it is losing to space
The temperature must then increase to get back into balance. The increase will not happen all at once! It will take time for energy to accumulate in the climate system. We want to model this
In fact almost all climate models are

children.value: This is a generically true statement.
We have just defined some terms, and made the (very good) assumption that the only significant energy sources are radiative exchanges with space.
This equation is the starting point for EVERY CLIMATE MODEL.

But so far, we don’t actually have a MODEL. We just have a statement of a budget. To use this budget to make a model, we need to relate terms in the budget to state variables of the atmosphere-ocean system.
For now, the state variable we are most interested in is
– because it is directly connected to the physics of each term above.

rho_w = 1E3  #  Density of water in kg/m3
H = 100.   #  Depth of water in m
C = c_w * rho_w * H   #  Heat capacity of the model 
print('The effective heat capacity is {:.1e} J/m2/K'.format(C))

children.html: TsT_sTs​

children.value: evolves from some specified initial condition) we have two choices:
Option 1 (analytical) will usually not be possible because the equations will typically be too complex and non-linear. This is why computers are our best friends in the world of climate modeling.
HOWEVER it is often useful and instructive to simplify a model down to something that is analytically solvable when possible. Why? Two reasons:
Analysis will often yield a deeper understanding of the behavior of the system
Gives us a benchmark against which to test the results of our numerical solutions.
6. Representing time derivatives on a computer

children.label: 6. Representing time derivatives on a computer

children.value: Recall that the derivative is the

children.html: dTdt=lim⁡Δt→0⁡ΔTΔt\frac{dT}{dt} = \lim_{\Delta t\rightarrow 0}⁡ \frac{\Delta T}{\Delta t}dtdT​=Δt→0lim​⁡ΔtΔT​

children.value: On the computer there is no such thing as an instantaneous change.
So we approximate the derivative with

children.html: ΔT/Δt\Delta T/ \Delta tΔT/Δt

children.value: So long as we take the time interval

children.html: Δt\Delta tΔt

children.value: “small enough”, the approximation is valid and useful.
(The meaning of “small enough” varies widely in practice. Let’s not talk about it now)
So we write our model as

ΔT\Delta TΔT

children.value: 7. Numerical solution of the Energy Balance Model

children.label: 7. Numerical solution of the Energy Balance Model

children.html: Δt\Delta tΔt

children.value: . It is the smallest time interval represented in our model.
Here we’re going to use a timestep of 1 year:
dt = 60. * 60. * 24. * 365.   # one year expressed in seconds

# Try a single timestep, assuming we have working functions for ASR and OLR
T1 = 288.
T2 = T1 + dt / C * ( ASR(alpha=0.32) - OLR(T1, tau=0.57) )
print(T2)
The code above assumes that we have already defined functions
. If you haven’t completed the exercise above, then the code won’t work.
Let’s now define the functions that we were supposed to create above:

# Try a single timestep, assuming we have working functions for ASR and OLR
T1 = 288.
T2 = T1 + dt / C * ( ASR(alpha=0.32) - OLR(T1, tau=0.57) )
print(T2)

T1 = T2
T2 = T1 + dt / C * ( ASR(alpha=0.32) - OLR(T1, tau=0.57) )
print(T2)
Warmed up again, but by a smaller amount.
But this is tedious typing. Time to
to make things easier and more reliable:

def step_forward(T):
    return T + dt / C * ( ASR(alpha=0.32) - OLR(T, tau=0.57) )
Try it out with an arbitrary temperature:
Notice that our function calls other functions and variables we have already defined.
Functions can access variables and other functions defined outside of the function.
This is both very useful and occasionally confusing.
Automate the timestepping with a loop

children.label: Automate the timestepping with a loop

children.value: Now let’s really harness the power of the computer by

import numpy as np

numsteps = 20
Tsteps = np.zeros(numsteps+1)
Years = np.zeros(numsteps+1)
Tsteps[0] = 288. 
for n in range(numsteps):
    Years[n+1] = n+1
    Tsteps[n+1] = step_forward( Tsteps[n] )
print(Tsteps)
set the initial temperature to 288 K
Stored the results of each time step into the array.
statement executes a statement (or series of statements) a specified number of times (a loop!)
Use square bracket [ ] to refer to elements of an array or list. Use round parentheses ( ) for function arguments.

If the planetary energy budget is out of balance, the temperature must change so that the
process: The rate of adjustment slows as the temperature approaches equilibrium.
The temperature gets very very close to equilibrium but never reaches it exactly.

Just about all of our notebooks will start with this:

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
We looked at the flows of energy in and out of the Earth system.
These are determined by radiation at the top of the Earth’s atmosphere.
Using this idea, we built a climate model!
